entry.title: Stranger Stats #5: The Buzz in January: A Recap of the Hornetsâ€™ Historic Month
entry.content:
As a NBA fan, I will have to admit that I rarely think about the Charlotte Hornets. To me, they always seem to be that team who is forever rebuilding. Each year they have high draft pick players, who show glimpse of stardom, and then as the season goes the team keeps on tanking and the cycle repeats itself.

This year, it was looking like just another regular â€œHornetsâ€ year. By December 31st, 2025, they have a 11 win / 22 loss record, ranked the 4th worst team in the Eastern Conference, and 7th worst team in the league.

HOWEVER, this Hornets team just had a HISTORICAL month in January 2026, straight up rolling towards the end of the month. Letâ€™s have a rundown of what they just accomplished.

1. Most Road Game Point Differential in a Calendar Month

Youâ€™d never expect a team with a 33% win percentage to tie the NBA record for most point differential in road games in a single calendar month, but amazingly the Hornets just did it! Letâ€™s take a look at the top 5 teams in the history in this category:

#1 Â· Miami Heat
2010-12 â€” MIA road month
Net +151 Â·+15.10/game Â·Rank: 1
Month 2010-12Road Record 10-0Net +151Net/game +15.10PF 1051PA 900
#2 Â· Charlotte Hornets
2026-01 â€” CHA road month
Net +151 Â·+13.73/game Â·Rank: 1
Month 2026-01Road Record 8-3Net +151Net/game +13.73PF 1336PA 1185
#3 Â· Boston Celtics
2022-02 â€” BOS road month
Net +136 Â·+19.43/game Â·Rank: 3
Month 2022-02Road Record 6-1Net +136Net/game +19.43PF 828PA 692
#4 Â· Oklahoma City Thunder
2025-11 â€” OKC road month
Net +132 Â·+16.50/game Â·Rank: 4
Month 2025-11Road Record 7-1Net +132Net/game +16.50PF 993PA 861
#5 Â· San Antonio Spurs
2014-03 â€” SAN road month
Net +131 Â·+18.71/game Â·Rank: 5
Month 2014-03Road Record 7-0Net +131Net/game +18.71PF 785PA 654

What elite company the Charlotte Hornets find themselves in. All other teams in the top 5 are all-time great teams who made it to the NBA finals that year, and two of them end up winning the chip!

So letâ€™s break down what teams they faced on the road:

2026-01 Charlotte Hornets Road Games
Swipe →
Date Opponent Score Diff Res
2026-01-02
Milwaukee Bucks
121â€“122 -1 L
2026-01-03
Chicago Bulls
112â€“99 +13 W
2026-01-05
Oklahoma City Thunder
124â€“97 +27 W
2026-01-10
Utah Jazz
150â€“95 +55 W
2026-01-12
Los Angeles Clippers
109â€“117 -8 L
2026-01-15
Los Angeles Lakers
135â€“117 +18 W
2026-01-17
Golden State Warriors
116â€“136 -20 L
2026-01-18
Denver Nuggets
110â€“87 +23 W
2026-01-22
Orlando Magic
124â€“97 +27 W
2026-01-28
Memphis Grizzlies
112â€“97 +15 W
2026-01-29
Dallas Mavericks
123â€“121 +2 W

Ahh now we see why Hornets came on top on this most point differential list despite losing 3 games: Most of their wins are blowout wins!. In particular, the +55 win against Utah Jazz alone counts as more than 1/3 of their net differential of the month. Itâ€™s worth nothing that this +55 win ranks #5 in the largest road-win margins in NBA history, just 2pts shy of the top spot.

Moreover, the Hornets also put up a string of true giant-slayer performances on the road. Coming to the enemiesâ€™ territory, they blew out an OKC team with the best record in the league by a wide margin, handled a Luka and LeBron led Lakers squad, and dismantled a hot Nuggets team that had been rolling even in JokiÄ‡â€™s absence.
These werenâ€™t narrow escapes or late-game coin flips. They were decisive wins. That deserves real credit. Itâ€™s a true testament to the Hornetsâ€™ offensive execution and shot-making ability, especially against elite competitions on the road.

2. A Six-Game Winning Streak (Last Seen in 2016)

Towards the end of the January, the Hornets is straight-up on fire, putting together a six-game winning streak:

Charlotte Hornets Current 6-Game Win streak (01/22/2026-01/31/2026)
Date Matchup Score Diff Res
2026-01-22
@ Orlando Magic
124â€“97 +27 W
2026-01-24
vs Washington Wizards
119â€“115 +4 W
2026-01-26
vs Philadelphia 76ers
130â€“93 +37 W
2026-01-28
@ Memphis Grizzlies
112â€“97 +15 W
2026-01-29
@ Dallas Mavericks
123â€“121 +2 W
2026-01-31
vs San Antonio Spurs
111â€“106 +5 W

The last time they won 6 straight or more was March of 2016, almost 10 years agao! That Hornets team features a young Kemba Walker and Nicholas Batum (who just began his first season with the Hornets, coming from Portland), with Jeremy Lin and Al Jefferson coming off the bench ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚. For real tho, checkout the box score for their win over the Suns. Man, that really brings back some nostalgia, doesnâ€™t it?

Charlotte Hornets Last 6-Game or More Win Streak (03/01/2016 â€“ 03/12/2016)
Date Matchup Score Diff Res
2016-03-01
vs Phoenix Suns
126â€“92 +34 W
2016-03-02
@ Philadelphia 76ers
119â€“99 +20 W
2016-03-04
vs Indiana Pacers
108â€“101 +7 W
2016-03-07
vs Minnesota Timberwolves
108â€“103 +5 W
2016-03-09
vs New Orleans Pelicans
122â€“113 +9 W
2016-03-11
vs Detroit Pistons
118â€“103 +15 W
2016-03-12
vs Houston Rockets
125â€“109 +16 W

To really put this in perspective, consider how recently other NBA teams have put together a 6-game (or longer) winning streak. For most franchises, the answer is very recent.

That said, a few teams stand out as having gone a bit longer without one. The Pelicans last reached a 6+ game streak in November 2022, ending a seven-game run. The Nets did it in January 2023, capping a massive 12-game streak (with their Big 3 in KD, Kyrie and the Beard). The Wizards last managed one in January 2023 as well, topping out at six straight wins.

But even those â€œlong gapsâ€ are only about three years ago.

For the Hornets, though, you have to go back nearly a decade.

That contrast says everything. For the first time in a while, the Hornets look like a team with real momentum, and it really just shows how special this current Hornets team has been. Hope they can keep on rolling and keep extending their win streak.

3. Putting the League on Notice

The Hornetsâ€™ recent surge hasnâ€™t gone unnoticed. As their January run caught fire, the recognition started accumulate for them, both at the individual and team level:

  • Charles Lee named Eastern Conference Coach of the Month
    A well-earned nod for orchestrating one of the Hornetsâ€™ most disciplined and consistent stretches in years.

  • Kon Knueppel named Eastern Conference Rookie of the Month
    Second straight for Kon. Is this the best rookie shooting weâ€™ve seen since Steph? The numbers are definitely suggesting so.

  • Brandon Miller named Eastern Conference Player of the Week (Week 15)
    Averaging 26.3 points, 5.8 rebounds and 2.3 assists in their 4-0 week. Well deserved!

  • Over the last 15 games: 1st in offensive rating and 1st in net rating
    Not just winning, they are dominating on both ends by the numbers.

entry.title: Stranger Stats #4: Too Young, Too Simple? Breaking Down the Youngest NBA Records Nobody Wants
entry.content:
Earlier this month, on January 7th, 2026, Ayden Heaven of Manchester United scored an own goal off an unfortunate deflection against Burnley, making him the youngest ever to score an Premier League own goal in Manchester United History, at 19 years and 107 days old.

Moments like this are brutal. Itâ€™s not the kind of record anyone wants attached to their name. But at the same time, simply being in position to set it is a testament to a playerâ€™s talent: a sign that they were asked and trusted to take on meaningful responsibility at a very young age, even if things didnâ€™t go their way. I think Ayden is having a solid season, and I hope in the future he can grow into an important piece at the back line of Manchester United.

This got me thinking: does the NBA have its own version of such moments?

Sure it does!

Sit back and let Stranger Stats take you on a tour through some youngest record holders for some embarrasing records in NBA history.

Among these, youâ€™ll find future stars who were working through early growth pains, as well as lottery-ticket players that some teams gambled on but were never able to cash in. Did they capitalize on their potential as they matured, or did they eventually become busts? You be the judge!

Youngest To Foul Out

Andris Biedrins

entry.title: Stranger Stats #3: He Shot 0/17 In an NBA Game, and 30 Years Later His Son Shot 0/12?
entry.content:
While watching Lakers vs. Bucks on the night of January 15, 2026, I witnessed two rough shooting lines unfold in real time: Kevin Porter Jr. went 0-for-8 for the Bucks, and Gabe Vincent finished 0-for-7 for the Lakers. Tough nights, no doubt.

But have you wondered who in the past has an even worse shooting performance? Let StrangerStats take you on a journey to uncover some of the worst â€œ0/X field goal attemptsâ€ games ever recorded.

1) Most field-goal attempts without a field goal

There are bad shooting nightsâ€¦ and then there are nights where you miss so many shots that it becomes a trivia question. The title for most field goal attempts without a single bucket belongs to Tim Hardaway Sr.. In 1991 he shot 0 for 17 in their win against the Timberwolves, and the record has stood for 35 years (and countingâ€¦).

Tim Hardaway
1991-12-27 â€” Golden State Warriors @ Minnesota Timberwolves (W)
FG 0/17 Â· 3P 0/2 Â· FT 2/2 Â· 2 PTS Â· 44 MIN
REB 3 AST 13 STL 2 BLK 1 TOV 4 PF 5 +/- +0

It was quite amazing that the Warriors were able to stil come away with a W! Despite his horrible shooting performance, Tim Hardaway Sr. dished out 13 assists and chipped in for the victory. His hall-of-fame teammate Chris Mullin did the heavy lifting. He shot 15 for 24 and scored 36 points, and covered for Hardawayâ€™s historically cold night.
Full box score on Basketball-Reference

The uncanny part is that 3 decades later, his son Tim Hardaway Jr. authored his own entry into this odd family trivia, shooting 0-for-12 from the field!! However, his team wasnâ€™t so lucky, as they got blown out by the Toronto Raptors. Full box score on Basketball-Reference

Tim Hardaway Jr.
2021-01-18 â€” Dallas Mavericks @ Toronto Raptors (L)
FG 0/12 Â· 3P 0/6 Â· FT 0/0 Â· 0 PTS Â· 26 MIN
REB 5 AST 1 STL 0 BLK 0 TOV 2 PF 1 +/- -12

2) Some all-time greatsâ€™ 0-for-X games

When we think shooting â€œ0-for-X,â€ we imagine role players having a panic-game. Start players have much more usage, more touches, and a better chance to play themselves into their rhythm. However there are times they just canâ€™t get right. Here are some 0 field goal games from star players:

Bill Russell
1965-01-23 â€” Boston Celtics @ Philadelphia 76ers (L)
FG 0/14 Â· 3P 0/0 Â· FT 4/7 Â· 4 PTS Â· 48 MIN
REB 17 AST 7 STL 0 BLK 0 TOV 0 PF 2 +/- +0
Vince Carter
2008-12-12 â€” New Jersey Nets vs Toronto Raptors (L)
FG 0/13 Â· 3P 0/2 Â· FT 3/4 Â· 3 PTS Â· 29 MIN
REB 4 AST 3 STL 0 BLK 0 TOV 3 PF 4 +/- -32
Russell Westbrook
2011-12-28 â€” Oklahoma City Thunder @ Memphis Grizzlies (W)
FG 0/13 Â· 3P 0/2 Â· FT 4/4 Â· 4 PTS Â· 31 MIN
REB 3 AST 6 STL 0 BLK 0 TOV 4 PF 3 +/- +1
Gilbert Arenas
2005-01-17 â€” Washington Wizards @ San Antonio Spurs (L)
FG 0/12 Â· 3P 0/4 Â· FT 3/4 Â· 3 PTS Â· 33 MIN
REB 2 AST 2 STL 0 BLK 0 TOV 2 PF 2 +/- -27
Chris Paul
2014-03-26 â€” Los Angeles Clippers @ New Orleans Pelicans (L)
FG 0/12 Â· 3P 0/3 Â· FT 2/2 Â· 2 PTS Â· 35 MIN
REB 4 AST 12 STL 3 BLK 0 TOV 2 PF 3 +/- +1

3) Most points scored with 0 made field goals

This is where things get weird.

How do you score a lot of points without making a single shot from the field?

Answer: free throws, and lots of them.

There you have it, one of the most weird games I found. Darrick Martin, who on this night could not make a single shot from the field (0/8 in FG), nailed all his free throws (15/15 in FT), making him the highest scorer without a single field goal bucket.

Darrick Martin
1996-12-14 â€” Los Angeles Clippers vs Sacramento Kings (W)
FG 0/8 Â· 3P 0/1 Â· FT 15/15 Â· 15 PTS Â· 32 MIN
REB 0 AST 7 STL 2 BLK 0 TOV 2 PF 4 +/- +20

4) The true nightmare: 0-for-X FG and 0-for-Y FT

Missing every field goal is bad.

Missing every free throw too? Thatâ€™s â€œturn off the phone for 48 hoursâ€ bad.

It turns out Joel Embiid and Kyrie Irving can trauma-bond over this experience, as both of them had a brutal night like this early in their respective careers.

Joel Embiid
2019-11-25 â€” Philadelphia 76ers @ Toronto Raptors (L)
FG 0/11 Â· 3P 0/4 Â· FT 0/3 Â· 0 PTS Â· 31 MIN
REB 13 AST 2 STL 0 BLK 0 TOV 4 PF 5 +/- -9
Kyrie Irving
2013-12-06 â€” Cleveland Cavaliers @ Atlanta Hawks (L)
FG 0/9 Â· 3P 0/3 Â· FT 0/3 Â· 0 PTS Â· 20 MIN
REB 4 AST 4 STL 0 BLK 0 TOV 0 PF 1 +/- -19

entry.title: Stranger Stats #2: LeBron Never Recorded His Career-Average Game (27/7/7), But Who Has?
entry.content:
This might be one of the NBAâ€™s most famous statistical trivia:

LeBron James has averaged 27 points, 7 rebounds, and 7 assists over his career â€” yet he has never once recorded a single game that matches those numbers exactly.

As of January 12, 2026, LeBron has played 1,581 regular-season games in 23 seasons, across three decades, 3 franchises, multiple positions/roles, and every possible game scenario, but the box score has never read:

27 points, 7 rebounds, 7 assists

Not even once.

This sounds quite impossible, right?

How Likely Is This, Really?

In fact, basketball fans have noticed this oddity for a long time now, and it turns out that itâ€™s not as implausible as it sounds.

To quantify this phenomenon, I found a insightful statistical analysis in which he models LeBron Jamesâ€™ points, rebounds, and assists using a correlated multivariate normal distribution. He estimates that the probability of LeBron not recording exactly 27/7/7 in any given game is $0.999064$. At the time of his post in 2019, LeBron had played 1,143 games, implying a probability of $0.999064^{1143} \approx 0.3429$ that he had not recorded a 27/7/7 stat line. This makes the outcome far more plausible than it initially sounds.

Fast forward to today (January 11, 2026), with seven additional seasons of data, I repeated the same analysis and found that the probability of LeBron still never having recorded a 27/7/7 has dropped to 0.2435. The likelyhood is pretty low, but itâ€™s definitely possible.

In other words: surprising, but far from impossible. Itâ€™s in fact very much within the realm of possibility.

Has Any Player Ever Matched Their Own Career Averages in a Game?

That brings us to a more interesting question.

Has any NBA player ever recorded a single game that exactly matched their own career averages?

To investivate this, I compared the career average stats for each NBA player (rounded to the nearest who numbers) against each game they every played, and try to see who has done it throughout the history.

Letâ€™s first look at other all-time great players besides LeBron James. In 2022, ESPN ranked the top 76 Players to ever play in the NBA. Taking that list and running through the test, we find a surprisingly even split: 39 players have recorded a game exactly matching their career averages at least once, while 37 have never done so**. Thatâ€™s almost a perfect 50â€“50 divide â€” a remarkable coincidence.

Some of the most iconic names in basketball history, Michael Jordan, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Kobe Bryant, and Bill Russell, never recorded a game that matched their career-average stat line. On the other hand, Hakeem Olajuwon accomplished this feat six times. Magic Johnson, Stephen Curry, and Kevin Durant each did it on two separate occasions.

Who Has Done it the Most Throughout the History?

If we look at all the players who played in the NBA, then Adonal Foyle is the champ based on this criterion. He recorded his rounded-off career average (4/5/0) 16 times during his 728-game NBA career:

Adonal Foyle
Career Avg: 4 / 5 / 0
Matched 16 times in 728 games

We can refine the results by imposing an arbitrary constraint where the sum of pts, rebs and assists must exeed 15 and the player must have played a minimum of 50 games. This filters out players with limited careers or had extremely low-usage roles, and leave us with some more recognizable names. It turns under this restriction, itâ€™s big Ben who wins! Ben Wallace record his career average 9 times in his 1082-game career.

Ben Wallace
Career Avg: 6 / 10 / 1
Matched 9 times in 1,082 games

Further Reading

Hope you enjoyed this blog. I did some google search and it turns out Iâ€™m not the first person to be curious about players recording exactly their career average stats. This reddit post from a few years ago also does a deep analysis and sparked some great discussions. Very intersting read!

entry.title: Stranger Stats #1: NBA Franchise Single-Game 3-Point Records Are Held by These Guys??
entry.content:
Whatâ€™s the first thing that you think about when I mention these names: Robert Covington, Marcus Smart, and Trevor Ariza, Kelly Oubre Jr., Danny Green, Wesley Matthews?

Solid defenders? Reliable role players? Classic 3 and D players that fit the modern style of basketball? All of that is true.

But thereâ€™s one thing they have in common that you probably wouldnâ€™t expect at all: each of them holds a franchise record for most three-pointers made in a single game.

Whaaaaat????

That might sound surprising, even a little wrong. When we think about single-game three-point records for NBA teams, our minds usually jump to the obvious names: Stephen Curry, Klay Thompson, Damian Lillard, James Harden â€¦ Superstars. Volume shooters. Offensive engines.

Yet franchise record holders are not always the star players.

This post is inspired by Julian Champagnieâ€˜s recent lights-out shooting performance vs. the New York Knicks on 12/31/2025. He made 11 threes in that game, setting a new franchise record for the San Antonio Spurs. This made me curious: who actually owns these single-game three-point records across the league? So I dug into the data and identified the record holder for each current NBA team. The table below is made on 01/05/2026 (With the rate people are shooting 3s in the league right now, none of these records are safe ğŸ˜‚, and we might comeback and update them). In cases where the record was tied, I kept every instance in a chronological order, from the earliest time to the most recent.

Did you see any surprising names?

Atlanta Hawks
Single-game record: 10 threes
  • Danilo Gallinari â€” 10/12 3PT, 2021-02-24 vs Boston Celtics
  • Bogdan Bogdanovic â€” 10/17 3PT, 2023-12-11 vs Denver Nuggets
Boston Celtics
Single-game record: 11 threes
  • Marcus Smart â€” 11/22 3PT, 2020-01-18 vs Phoenix Suns
Brooklyn Nets
Single-game record: 11 threes
  • Deron Williams â€” 11/16 3PT, 2013-03-08 vs Washington Wizards
Charlotte Hornets
Single-game record: 10 threes
  • Kemba Walker â€” 10/14 3PT, 2018-03-22 vs Memphis Grizzlies
  • Devonte' Graham â€” 10/16 3PT, 2019-12-04 vs Golden State Warriors
  • Terry Rozier â€” 10/16 3PT, 2020-12-23 @ Cleveland Cavaliers
  • Kelly Oubre Jr. â€” 10/15 3PT, 2022-01-26 @ Indiana Pacers
Chicago Bulls
Single-game record: 13 threes
  • Zach LaVine â€” 13/17 3PT, 2019-11-23 @ Charlotte Hornets
Cleveland Cavaliers
Single-game record: 11 threes
  • Kyrie Irving â€” 11/19 3PT, 2015-01-28 vs Portland Trail Blazers
Dallas Mavericks
Single-game record: 10 threes
  • George McCloud â€” 10/12 3PT, 1995-12-16 vs Phoenix Suns
  • Wesley Matthews â€” 10/17 3PT, 2015-12-06 @ Washington Wizards
  • Tim Hardaway Jr. â€” 10/18 3PT, 2021-05-04 @ Miami Heat
Denver Nuggets
Single-game record: 11 threes
  • JR Smith â€” 11/18 3PT, 2009-04-13 vs Sacramento Kings
Detroit Pistons
Single-game record: 10 threes
  • Joe Dumars â€” 10/18 3PT, 1994-11-08 vs Minnesota Timberwolves

entry.title: My 2022 Weight Loss Journey
entry.content:
In 2022, I set out on an important personal project of my life: taking control of my health and fitness.

Where I Started

Around beginning of July 2022, I was at my heaviest in my entire life, at an appalling 327 pounds.


Why I did it?

Looking back, I remember exactly why I decided to do it. I donâ€™t take pictures often and I donâ€™t post on social media. But that summer when my best friend in college came to visit me in Seattle, we had an awesome time and took many pictures. Only after I looked the pictures did I realize how far Iâ€™ve let myself go, and I know Iâ€™ve got to put and end to this.

Iâ€™ve been fat before, and Iâ€™ve been thin before. I grew up as a chubby kid (with great agility on the basketball court, believe or not), and I once lost 90 pounds in one semester in college. After the pandemic, I learned how to cook and perhaps fed myself a bit too well. Iâ€™ve always thought that I knew my body, and that once I decided to lose weight, I could get in shape again. However, the giant task that stood before me was to lose 110 pounds, which was DAUNTING to say the least.

Hence, I decided to track my progress, as a way to hold myself accountable and push me to keep going on my weight loss journey.

Where I ended up

By 11/07/2022 (which is my last recorded weight), I had lost over 100 lbs. Here, I will show you some proof:


Progress Tracking

Like I mentioned, to hold myself accountable, Iâ€™ve been recording my weight and other stats (from a Renpho smart scale) first thing in the morning. If you are interested in how Iâ€™m doing the analysis below, feel free to check out my github repo.

In this plot, I show my overall progress in terms of my weight, BMI and body fat. The best line fit for each set of data is shown in the upper right corner.

To zoom in to each phase during the journey, I plotted my segmented progress, at each 10-day interval.

Reflections

I want to make some comments, and summarize the thing Iâ€™ve learned during this journey. If you are reading this, hopefully you can find something useful!

  • Break down the big task into small tasks. 110 pounds seem daunting, but all you need to worry about is the 4-5 pounds this week. Set small goals and conquer it. Once you get into a good rhythm, you will be very motivated to keep it going.
  • Data keep your honest. You need to consistenly keep an entry to track where you are at. The challenge is both mental and physical. By keeping an record (and doing some simple data analysis), you can monitor the pace that you are on, and reflect on how much youâ€™ve done. Once you visualize the progress, youâ€™d appreciate the effort youâ€™ve put in, which can definitely give you extra motivation to stay committed and keep it going.
  • Consistency is the most important thing. For me, the one cardio I can make sure that I consistently do everyday is indoor cycling. This is because on an exercise bike, I can free my hands and play video games (2k and FIFA~) while I put in the work. If you need to lose weight also, you can choose whatever you feel like you can keep a habit of doing. It doesnâ€™t matter if itâ€™s the most efficient or â€œthe bestâ€ excercise. You want to pick the one thatâ€™s right for you.
  • You are going to have off days. Some days you have enough motivation to do it, some other days you might not be able to get up to it. Thatâ€™s okay! Take a day off, regroup, and come back at the problem more focused than ever!
  • If I have to do this all over again, I would probably do whole weight loss at a slower pace. My mindset was to plow through it as fast as I can so I donâ€™t need to suffer too long. But losing weight too fast caused parts of my skin to be loose. Also Iâ€™ve dropped tons of muscle mass along the way, in addition to fat. If you are looking to lose weight, then the best and most healthy pace should be around losing 1% of body weight every week.

entry.title: Welcome
entry.content:
Hi, Iâ€™m Aodong Liu, a PhD candidate in theoretical chemistry at the University of Washington. You can learn more about what I do here

This is my personal blog. On this site Iâ€™ll share a mix of things that matter to me:

  • Research Notes: Technical deep-dives, quantum chemistry tutorials, and reflections on my journey as a computational scientist.
  • Stranger Stats: Iâ€™m fascinated by sports statistics (though Iâ€™m not a data scientist by training), so I occasionally share fun and unexpected findings in Stranger Stats.
  • Personal: Sometimes about training, fitness, or just things I find inspiring.

This site is still under construction, but it will grow as I document my projects and ideas.

Stay tuned ğŸš€
